title: 114_s2715
content: The Act is titled the "National Security Whistleblower Protection Act of 2016" and addresses the suspension or revocation of access to classified information. The Act, titled the "National Security Whistleblower Protection Act of 2016," amends Section 2302(a)(2)(A) of title 5, United States Code, to include the suspension or revocation of access to classified information. Section 2303(a) is also amended to include clause (xii) for the FBI. Additionally, the Inspector General of the Department of Defense is required to submit a report. The National Security Whistleblower Protection Act of 2016 amends Section 2302(a)(2)(A) of title 5, United States Code to include actions related to whistleblowing. The Inspector General of the Department of Defense must submit a report to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The National Security Whistleblower Protection Act of 2016 requires the Inspector General to include information in semiannual reports to Congress regarding the number of allegations received for each category of employee. The Inspector General must report the number of whistleblower allegations regarding classified information access being suspended or revoked in retaliation, closed without full investigation, and fully investigated. The Inspector General conducted a full investigation on whistleblower allegations of classified information access being suspended or revoked in retaliation. Additionally, investigations conducted by other Department of Defense components were reported. The Inspector General oversaw investigations of whistleblower allegations regarding classified information access. Remedial measures were taken, and disciplinary actions were implemented for individuals involved in suspending or revoking access to classified information. Employees in the Department of Defense, nonappropriated fund instrumentalities, and regular Armed Forces members may have their access to classified information suspended or revoked in retaliation for whistleblowing. Employees in the Department of Defense, including members of the Armed Forces, National Guard, contractors, and other categories of employees, may have their access to classified information suspended for whistleblowing.
